para.paratext: Fed. R. Evid. 606(b) and O.C.G.A. 24-6-606(b) provide:

Upon an inquiry into the validity of a verdict or indictment, a juror shall not testify by affidavit or otherwise nor shall a juror's statements be received in evidence as to any matter or statements occurring during the course of the jury's deliberations or to the effect of anything upon the jury deliberations or any other juror's mind or emotions as influencing the juror to assent to or dissent from the verdict or indictment or concerning the juror's mental processes in connection therewith; provided, however, that a juror may testify on the question of whether extraneous prejudicial information was improperly brought to the jury's attention, whether any outside influence was improperly brought to bear upon any juror, or whether there was a mistake in entering the verdict onto the verdict form.

This rule bars inquiries into the validity of the indictment itself.[1] Fed. R. Crim. P. 6(e) provides an exception to the federal evidence rule in that it permits disclosure when “directed” or “permitted” by the court.

O.C.G.A. § 24-6-606(b) also governs what is or is not admissible to sustain or impeach a verdict. Thus, a juror may only give testimony concerning extraneous prejudicial information or improper outside influences; however, the juror may not provide testimony or evidence regarding anything that happened during deliberations, the juror's mental processes, or the reason the jury reached a particular verdict. Jurors may also testify as to a mistake on the verdict form.[2]

Accordingly, when brought before the court, the trial court must only determine if extraneous prejudicial information was improperly brought to the jury's attention or if any outside influence was improperly brought to bear upon any juror. The court may only inquire into the existence of extraneous information, and not into the subjective effect of such information on the particular jurors.[3]
See Tanner v. U.S., 483 U.S. 107, 107 S. Ct. 2739, 97 L. Ed. 2d 90, 22 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1143 (1987).
United States v. Foster, 878 F.3d 1297, 105 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 386 (11th Cir. 2018).
